newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: Swiss stocks end nearly 1.5 percent lower.
newsitem.headline: Swiss stocks end nearly 1.5 percent lower.

text.p: Swiss shares posted a sixth consecutive fall on Friday to close nearly 1.5 percent lower on the back of weaker opening U.S. markets, a sagging dollar and derivatives-related selling.
Dealers said the Swiss correction was reinforced by falling Standard & Poor's futures. "This got our derivatives machinery going," one trader said.
High-profile stocks took the brunt of the losses.
One dealer said the downward move may now have bottomed out, but others warned the slide may not be over yet.
The blue-chip Swiss Market Index (SMI) down 81.0 points or 1.45 percent to 5,498.5.
The broad Swiss Performance Index (SPI) fell 48.87 points or 1.36 percent to 3,547.03 points.
Bourse volume was at 3.29 billion Swiss francs.
The expiry of August contracts on Swiss Options and Financial Futures Exchange (Soffex) was described as smooth.
Views on further developments were mixed.
"There are opportunities now for bargain hunting," one dealer said.
However, one technical analyst recently argued that the slide may continue to intra-day lows of 5,370 SMI points before the market could rebound to a range between 5,500 and 6,000 points.

Pharmaceutical Roche, which said first-half net profit rose 10 percent to 2,428 million francs, had a see-saw session with a high of 13,650 and a low of 13,020. The certificates ended down 65 francs at 13,325.
Dealers said some investors who had hoped for higher profit growth sold the stock.
Novartis registereds, which led the actives list, ended off 42 rancs at 2,177.
CS Group and Winterthur recouped some of the losses incurred since they announced merger plans. CS Group was down 0.25 francs to 186. Winterthur up eight to 1,380.
